1. Review all four fraction operations and when to use each.
2. Teach problem-solving strategies: identify what you know, what you need to find, and which operation applies.
3. Model solving a multi-step fraction problem.
4. Students work through a set of real-world problems independently.
5. Discuss strategies and compare solution methods.
6. End-of-week fraction skills assessment.

slides.text: Choosing the right operation: ADD when combining amounts ('How much total?'). SUBTRACT when finding differences ('How much more?' or 'How much is left?'). MULTIPLY when finding a fraction OF something ('What is 2/3 of 24?'). DIVIDE when splitting into fractional groups ('How many 1/4-cup servings in 3 cups?').

Multi-step problem example: 'You are building a bookshelf. Each shelf needs 3 1/4 feet of wood. You need 4 shelves. The wood comes in 8-foot boards. How many boards do you need?' Step 1: Total wood needed = 3 1/4 × 4 = 13/4 × 4/1 = 52/4 = 13 feet. Step 2: Boards needed = 13 ÷ 8 = 1 5/8 boards. Step 3: You cannot buy 5/8 of a board, so you need 2 boards. Always consider the real-world context!

Problem-solving checklist: (1) Read the problem twice. (2) Identify the information given. (3) Identify what you need to find. (4) Decide which operation(s) to use. (5) Estimate before calculating. (6) Solve step by step, showing all work. (7) Check: Does my answer make sense in context?

slides.prompt: Solve these real-world problems. Show all work and estimate first. (1) A hiking trail is 5 3/4 miles long. You have walked 2 1/3 miles. How much farther do you have to go? (2) A recipe for 12 muffins uses 2/3 cup sugar. You want to make 18 muffins. How much sugar do you need? (3) A garden is 8 1/2 feet by 6 2/3 feet. What is its area? (4) You have 15 3/4 feet of ribbon. Each bow needs 2 1/4 feet. How many complete bows can you make? How much ribbon is left over? (5) Three friends share a bill. The bill is $45. One pays 1/3, one pays 2/5, and the third pays the rest. How much does each person pay?

slides.text: This week you reviewed equivalent fractions, added and subtracted with unlike denominators, multiplied and divided fractions, worked with mixed numbers, and applied all of these skills to real-world problems. Fractions are everywhere — cooking, building, sharing, measuring. Mastering them gives you power over the numbers in everyday life.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify the correct operation for fraction word problems and solve multi-step problems involving fractions and mixed numbers?

parent_notes: This lesson synthesizes the entire week of fraction work. The real-world problems are intentionally varied to require different operations and some multi-step thinking. Problem 4 (ribbon and bows) requires division with a remainder interpreted in context — you cannot make a partial bow, so the answer must be rounded down, with the leftover calculated. Problem 5 introduces the idea that fractions must add to 1 (the whole bill). If your child struggles to identify the correct operation, focus on the keywords and context clues listed in the instruction slides. Consider making this a weekly pattern: four days of skill building, one day of application and assessment. If your child has mastered fractions, they are ready for the ratio and proportion work coming in Week 7.

title: Mapping Human Migration — Population Genetics and Diversity
description: Students explore how human migration patterns created the genetic diversity we see today. They study how isolated populations developed different physical adaptations (skin color, body proportions) in response to environment, and learn that race is a social construct with no basis in genetics — all humans share 99.9% of their DNA.
instructions:
1. Review migration routes from Day 1.
2. Explain how isolation and environment led to physical adaptations: skin color and UV radiation, body proportions and climate.
3. Present the genetic evidence: all humans share 99.9% DNA; more genetic diversity exists within Africa than between any two other continents.
4. Discuss: Why is 'race' not a biological category? What is it?
5. Connect to Mendel: How do dominant/recessive traits spread through populations?
6. Student completes a migration and adaptation analysis.

slides.text: As small groups of humans migrated to different environments over tens of thousands of years, natural selection favored different traits in different places. This is adaptation — the same process we studied in evolution. Importantly, these differences are literally skin-deep: they involve a tiny fraction of our total DNA (less than 0.1% of human genes differ between populations).

Skin color: Near the equator, dark skin protects against UV radiation, which can destroy folate (a vitamin essential for healthy babies). Far from the equator, lighter skin allows more UV to penetrate, which is needed to produce vitamin D. Skin color is an adaptation to UV levels, nothing more. It involves just a handful of genes out of 20,000+.

Body proportions: In cold climates, natural selection favored compact bodies with shorter limbs (less surface area = less heat loss). In hot climates, taller, leaner bodies with longer limbs were favored (more surface area = better cooling). These are the same principles of physics — they apply to all mammals, not just humans. Think of the difference between an Arctic fox and a desert fox.

The genetic truth: There is more genetic diversity WITHIN Africa than between Africa and any other continent. This means two people from different parts of Africa may be more genetically different from each other than either is from a person in Europe or Asia. Why? Because Homo sapiens lived in Africa for 200,000+ years before small groups left. The migrants carried only a fraction of Africa's genetic diversity with them.

slides.prompt: Using your migration map and a world climate map: (1) Identify three regions where humans settled and describe the climate. (2) Predict what physical adaptations might be favored in each region and explain why. (3) Write a paragraph answering: 'Why do scientists say that race is a social construct rather than a biological reality?' Use at least three facts from today's lesson. (4) Bonus: Research one additional human adaptation to environment (e.g., Tibetan adaptation to high altitude, Inuit adaptation to cold, lactose tolerance in pastoral societies).

slides.text: Human diversity is real and beautiful — but it represents tiny variations on an overwhelmingly shared genetic blueprint. We are one species, with one origin, adapted to many environments. Understanding the science of human variation helps us appreciate diversity while recognizing our fundamental unity.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain at least two examples of environmental adaptation in human populations? Can they explain why genetic diversity is greatest in Africa?

parent_notes: This is an important and sensitive lesson that addresses race from a scientific perspective. The key message: physical differences between human populations are real but superficial, involving a tiny fraction of our genes, and they result from adaptation to different environments — not from fundamental biological differences. The concept that race is a social construct (meaning societies create racial categories, and these categories vary between cultures and change over time) is supported by the American Anthropological Association, the American Association of Physical Anthropologists, and the Human Genome Project. If your child asks difficult questions about racism or prejudice, this is a good opportunity to discuss how misunderstanding of human variation has been used to justify inequality, and how science provides the antidote: knowledge that we are one species. Be honest, age-appropriate, and affirming of diversity.

title: Storytelling Traditions — Oral History and Memory
description: Students explore the ancient art of oral storytelling, studying how cultures without writing preserved history, laws, values, and knowledge through spoken tradition. They learn memory techniques used by oral cultures (rhythm, repetition, vivid imagery) and practice by memorizing and retelling a traditional story.
instructions:
1. Discuss: How did people remember important information before writing was invented?
2. Explore oral traditions: West African griots, Aboriginal Australian songlines, Polynesian navigation chants, Native American winter counts.
3. Study memory techniques: rhythm, repetition, alliteration, vivid imagery, story structure.
4. Read a short traditional folktale together.
5. Student memorizes and retells the story using memory techniques.
6. Discuss: What do we lose when oral traditions disappear?
materials_needed: Collection of folktales or myths (printed or read aloud)

slides.heading: The Power of the Spoken Word

slides.text: For most of human history — about 290,000 of our 300,000 years — there was no writing. Everything that mattered was stored in human memory and passed down through spoken word: history, laws, scientific knowledge, religious beliefs, navigation routes, medicinal recipes, and moral lessons. Oral tradition was humanity's first and longest-lasting information technology.

Griots of West Africa are hereditary storytellers, historians, and musicians. They memorize the genealogies and histories of entire kingdoms — some griots can recite family histories spanning 40 generations (1,000+ years). In the Sunjata epic, griots preserve the founding story of the Mali Empire. Their training begins in childhood and lasts decades.

Aboriginal Australian Songlines are oral maps that describe the creation journeys of ancestral spirits across the landscape. By singing the correct songs in the correct order, a person could navigate across thousands of miles of desert — land they had never personally visited. The songs encode geographical information, water sources, and seasonal food locations. These songlines have been maintained for at least 10,000 years.

Memory techniques used by oral cultures: (1) Rhythm and rhyme — easier to remember than prose, (2) Repetition — key phrases repeated for emphasis and recall, (3) Vivid imagery — memorable mental pictures, (4) Story structure — beginning, middle, end with a clear arc, (5) Physical movement — gestures and dance accompanying words, (6) Musical melody — information set to tune.

slides.prompt: Choose a short folktale or myth (your parent can help select one, or use one we have studied). Read it three times. Then close the text and retell it in your own words, using these memory techniques: create vivid mental images for key scenes, identify repeating patterns, add rhythm to important phrases. Practice retelling until you can do it without notes. Then perform your story for a family member — use gestures, vocal expression, and eye contact. In your journal, write: Which memory techniques worked best for you? What is lost when stories are written down instead of told aloud?

slides.text: Oral storytelling is not a primitive technology replaced by writing — it is a sophisticated art that activates memory, community, and imagination in ways that written text cannot. When a griot speaks, the audience participates. When a songline is sung, the land comes alive. As we move into our study of writing systems next week, remember what writing gained and what it lost.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify at least three oral storytelling traditions and explain at least two memory techniques? Can they retell a story from memory?

parent_notes: This lesson bridges our study of early humans with the upcoming unit on writing systems. It challenges the assumption that oral cultures were 'primitive' — in fact, they developed extraordinarily sophisticated memory systems. The griot tradition, Aboriginal songlines, and Polynesian navigation chants represent cognitive achievements comparable to any technology. The retelling activity is powerful: children often discover they are better at remembering and telling stories than they expected. For the folktale, you might choose an Anansi story (West African), a pourquoi tale (why stories), or a myth your family connects with culturally. The act of performing for an audience — making eye contact, using gestures, varying tone — builds confidence and communication skills that extend far beyond this lesson.

title: Read-Aloud: 'The Evolution of Calpurnia Tate' — Chapters 7-9
description: Continue reading the novel, focusing on Calpurnia's deepening scientific investigations and the growing tension between her intellectual pursuits and her family's expectations. Students analyze theme development and practice making text-to-self and text-to-world connections.
instructions:
1. Review chapters 4-6: What has Calpurnia learned? How is her relationship with her grandfather developing?
2. Read chapters 7-9 aloud.
3. Discuss emerging themes: curiosity vs. conformity, the role of mentors, change and growth.
4. Make connections: text-to-self (How does this relate to my life?), text-to-world (How does this relate to our history/science studies?).
5. Analyze a key passage closely: What is the author doing with word choice and imagery?
6. Journal: Write about a mentor in your life.
materials_needed: The Evolution of Calpurnia Tate by Jacqueline Kelly

slides.text: Before reading, review: What scientific observations has Calpurnia been making? How is her grandfather guiding her? What conflicts has she experienced between her interests and her family's expectations? Make a prediction: What do you think will happen next?

As we read chapters 7-9, we will practice three types of connections: Text-to-Self — 'This reminds me of when I...' Text-to-Text — 'This is similar to another book/story where...' Text-to-World — 'This connects to what we have been learning about...' Strong readers make connections constantly — it is how we make meaning from what we read.

Read chapters 7-9, pausing at key moments to discuss and make connections. Pay special attention to: How does the author use nature descriptions to reflect Calpurnia's inner world? What do we learn about Calpurnia's mother and her values? How does the 1899 setting shape the story differently than if it were set today?

slides.prompt: After reading, choose one: (1) Text-to-World Connection: Write a paragraph connecting something in these chapters to our study of genetics, evolution, or human history. How does what Calpurnia is learning relate to what we have been studying? (2) Mentor Reflection: Calpurnia's grandfather is her mentor. Write about a mentor in your life — someone who has helped you see the world differently. How did they teach you? What have you learned from them? (3) Close Reading: Choose one paragraph from today's reading that you found powerful. Copy it in your journal and write an analysis: What is the author doing with word choice, imagery, or sentence structure? Why is this passage effective?

slides.text: The best books change how we see the world. Calpurnia's story is not just about science in 1899 — it is about the courage to be curious, the power of mentorship, and the tension between being who you are and being who others expect you to be. These are timeless themes that connect to every reader's life.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student make meaningful text-to-self and text-to-world connections? Can they identify and discuss emerging themes in the novel?

parent_notes: Making connections (text-to-self, text-to-text, text-to-world) is a key reading comprehension strategy that good readers do automatically. Modeling this for your child is powerful: as you read aloud, pause and share your own connections ('This reminds me of...' or 'This connects to what we learned about...'). The close reading option is excellent for developing analytical skills — choosing a single paragraph and examining the author's craft teaches students to read like writers. The mentor reflection is personally meaningful and helps children articulate gratitude and awareness of influential relationships in their lives. Adjust reading pace to your child's interest — if they are deeply engaged, read more; if attention is waning, read less and discuss more.
